_comment: Created by EFisher on 12/10/2015 14:29:30 using v2.7
title: How have employment rates changed?
analysis_commentary: It is estimated that around one quarter of working age adults have one or more long-term conditions (LTCs), and employment rates for this group are around 60% - typically 10-15% lower than for the general population. Trends in employment in the general population showed a fall between 2007 and 2010, whereas employment of people with LTCs was broadly steady. This resulted in a narrowing of the gap between the two rates (from 15% in 2006 to 11% in 2010). Through 2011 both rates remained similar to 2010 levels. From mid-2013, employment has been increasing in both groups. This resulted in a the highest employment rate seen in people with LTCs in 2014/15 Q4 of 60.5%. The gap between the two groups however has not decreased.
